se.softhouse.jargo

Class ArgumentBuilder<SELF extends ArgumentBuilder<SELF,T>,T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • se.softhouse.jargo.ArgumentBuilder<SELF,T>
  • Type Parameters:
    SELF - the type of the subclass extending this class. Concept borrowed from: Ansgar.Konermann's blog The pattern also resembles the Curiously recurring template pattern
    T - the type of arguments the built Argument instance should handle, such as Integer in the case of Arguments.integerArgument(String...)
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ArgumentBuilder.CommandBuilder, ArgumentBuilder.DefaultArgumentBuilder, ArgumentBuilder.ListArgumentBuilder, ArgumentBuilder.MapArgumentBuilder, ArgumentBuilder.OptionArgumentBuilder, ArgumentBuilder.TransformingArgumentBuilder

    @NotThreadSafe
public abstract class ArgumentBuilder<SELF extends ArgumentBuilder<SELF,T>,T>
extends Object
     Responsible for configuring and building Argument instances.
 Example builders can be created with Arguments.

 Note:The code examples (for each method) assumes that all methods in Arguments have been statically imported.

 Note:Some methods needs to be called in a specific order
 (to make the generic type system produce the correct type) and to guide the
 caller, such invalid orders are documented with Deprecated. If those warnings
 are ignored IllegalStateException will be thrown at the offending call.

      Builder for Commands.

      A very simple version of an ArgumentBuilder, it's exposed mainly to lessen the exposure of the SELF_TYPE argument of the ArgumentBuilder.

      An intermediate builder used by asPropertyMap().

      An intermediate builder used by repeated().

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Modifier Constructor and Description
      protected ArgumentBuilder()
      Creates a default ArgumentBuilder that produces arguments that: doesn't have any names(String...) has an empty description(String) isn't required() uses StringParser.defaultValue() on parser() to produce default values uses Object.toString() to describe the default value uses StringParser.metaDescription() on parser() to produce meta descriptions doesn't have any limits Typically invoked implicitly by subclasses.

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      ArgumentBuilder.ArityArgumentBuilder<T> arity(int numberOfParameters)
      Uses this argument to parse values but assumes that numberOfParameters of the following parameters are of the same type.
      <K> ArgumentBuilder.MapArgumentBuilder<K,T> asKeyValuesWithKeyParser(StringParser<K> keyParser)
      Makes this argument handle properties like arguments: -Dproperty_name=value where "-D" is one of the strings supplied to names(String...), "property_name" is decoded by keyParser and "value" is decoded by the StringParser previously passed to the constructor.
      ArgumentBuilder.MapArgumentBuilder<String,T> asPropertyMap()
      Makes this argument handle "property like" arguments: -Dproperty_name=value where "-D" is the string supplied to names(String...), "property_name" is the String key in the resulting Map, "=" is the separator(String) (set to "=" if it hasn't been overridden already), "value" is decoded by the previously set StringParser.
      Argument<T> build()
      Returns an Immutable Argument which can be passed to CommandLineParser.withArguments(Argument...)
      When the parsing is done the parsed value for this argument can be fetched with ParsedArguments.get(Argument).

      Can be used to complete input values from a dynamic (or static) source.

      By default StringParsers provides a meta description (by implementing StringParser.metaDescription() that describes the type of data they expect.

      Makes it possible to chain together different transformation / map / conversion operations 
       
 int size = Arguments.stringArgument("--foo").transform(String::length).parse("--foo", "abcd");
 assertThat(size).isEqualTo(4);

      Returns a usage string for the argument that this builder builds.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ArgumentBuilder

        protected ArgumentBuilder()
        Creates a default ArgumentBuilder that produces arguments that:
        • doesn't have any names(String...)
        • has an empty description(String)
        • isn't required()
        • uses StringParser.defaultValue() on parser() to produce default values
        • uses Object.toString() to describe the default value
        • uses StringParser.metaDescription() on parser() to produce meta descriptions
        • doesn't have any limits
        Typically invoked implicitly by subclasses.

    • Method Detail

      • arity

        @CheckReturnValue
public ArgumentBuilder.ArityArgumentBuilder<T> arity(int numberOfParameters)
         Uses this argument to parse values but assumes that  numberOfParameters of the
 following parameters are of the same type.

 Integer in the following example:
 
         
 List<Integer> numbers = integerArgument("--numbers").arity(2).parse("--numbers", "1", "2");
 assertThat(numbers).isEqualTo(asList(1, 2));
        Note:If the argument isn't required() the default value will be a list that contains numberOfParameters elements of StringParser.defaultValue(), in the above example that would be two zeros. If this isn't wanted use defaultValue(Object) to override it.
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if numberOfParameters is less than 2

      • asKeyValuesWithKeyParser

        @CheckReturnValue
public final <K> ArgumentBuilder.MapArgumentBuilder<K,T> asKeyValuesWithKeyParser(StringParser<K> keyParser)
         Makes this argument handle properties like arguments:
 -Dproperty_name=value
 where "-D" is one of the strings supplied to names(String...),
 "property_name" is decoded by  keyParser and
 "value" is decoded by the StringParser previously passed to the constructor.

 For example:
 
         
 Map<Integer, Integer> numberMap = Arguments.integerArgument("-N")
                                                .asKeyValuesWithKeyParser(StringParsers.integerParser())
                                                .parse("-N1=5", "-N2=10");
 assertThat(numberMap.get(1)).isEqualTo(5);
        For this to work correctly it's paramount that K implements a proper Object.hashCode() because it's going to be used a key in a Map.
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder

      • asPropertyMap

        @CheckReturnValue
public final ArgumentBuilder.MapArgumentBuilder<String,T> asPropertyMap()
         Makes this argument handle "property like" arguments:
 -Dproperty_name=value
 where
 "-D" is the string supplied to names(String...),
 "property_name" is the String key in the resulting Map,
 "=" is the separator(String) (set to "=" if it hasn't been overridden already),
 "value" is decoded by the previously set StringParser.


 Tip: You can pass defaultValueDescriber(Describer) a
 Describers.mapDescriber(Map) to describe each property that you
 support (given that you've used defaultValue(Object)
 to use sane defaults for your properties).

 @return a new (more specific) builder
        See Also:
        to use other types as keys than {@link String}

      • build

        @CheckReturnValue
 @Nonnull
public final Argument<T> build()
        Returns an Immutable Argument which can be passed to CommandLineParser.withArguments(Argument...)
        When the parsing is done the parsed value for this argument can be fetched with ParsedArguments.get(Argument).
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if it's not possible to construct an Argument with the current settings

      • completer

        public SELF completer(Function<String,Set<String>> aCompleter)
        Can be used to complete input values from a dynamic (or static) source. For example 
         

 stringArgument("-u", "--username").completer((str) -> StringsUtil.prefixes(str, service.users()));
        Where service.users() would return the name of all your users. StringsUtil.prefixes(String, java.util.Collection) is a convenient friend method to easily filter out usernames that does not match str (in this case).
        Parameters:
        aCompleter - function that takes in a part of a parameter and returns a set of strings that would make this parameter a valid one

      • defaultValue

        public SELF defaultValue(@Nullable
                         T value)
         Sets a default value to use for this argument. Overrides StringParser.defaultValue() which is used by default.
 Returned by ParsedArguments.get(Argument) when no argument was given.
 To create default values lazily see defaultValueSupplier(Supplier).
        Mutability:Remember that as Argument is Immutable this value should be so too if multiple argument parsings is going to take place. If mutability is wanted defaultValueSupplier(Supplier) should be used instead.
        Returns:
        this builder
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if required() has been called, because these two methods are mutually exclusive

      • defaultValueDescriber

        public SELF defaultValueDescriber(Describer<? super T> describer)
        Describer version of defaultValueDescription(String)
        Parameters:
        describer - a describer
        Returns:
        this builder

      • defaultValueDescription

        public SELF defaultValueDescription(String aDescription)
        Provides a way to give the usage texts a better explanation of a default value than Object.toString() provides. Always prints aDescription regardless of what the default value is.
        Parameters:
        aDescription - the description
        Returns:
        this builder
        See Also:
        Describers.withConstantString(String)

      • defaultValueSupplier

        public SELF defaultValueSupplier(Supplier<? extends T> aDefaultValueSupplier)
         Sets a Supplier that can supply default values in the absence of this argument
        Note: Even if limitTo(Predicate) is used, the Supplier.get() isn't called until the default value is actually needed (ParsedArguments.get(Argument). If the default value is deemed non-allowed at that point an IllegalStateException is thrown. Wrap your supplier with Suppliers2.memoize(Supplier) if you want to cache created values.
        Returns:
        this builder
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if required() has been called, because these two methods are mutually exclusive

      • description

        public final SELF description(Describable theDescription)
         Describable version of description(String).
 @return this builder

      • description

        public final SELF description(String theDescription)
         Sets  theDescription of what this argument does/means. Printed with
 CommandLineParser.usage().

 For instance, in:
 -l, --enable-logging      Output debug information to standard out
                           Default: disabled
 "Output debug information to standard out" is  theDescription
 @return this builder

      • hideFromUsage

        public final SELF hideFromUsage()
        Hides this argument so that it's not displayed in the usage texts.
        It's recommended that hidden arguments have a reasonable defaultValue(Object) and aren't required(), in fact this is recommended for all arguments. TODO(jontejj): hidden args should not be completable with CommandLineParser.completer(Completer)?
        Returns:
        this builder

      • ignoreCase

        public final SELF ignoreCase()
        Ignores the case of the argument names set by names(String...)
        Returns:
        this builder

      • limitTo

        public SELF limitTo(Predicate<? super T> aLimiter)
         Limits values parsed so that they conform to some specific rule.
 Only values for which Predicate.test(Object) returns true, will be accepted.
 Other values will cause an ArgumentException.

 To override the default error message that is generated with Texts.UserErrors.DISALLOWED_VALUE
 you can throw IllegalArgumentException from Predicate.test(Object). The detail
 message of that exception will be used by ArgumentException.getMessageAndUsage().
 When this is needed it's generally recommended to write a parser of its own instead.

 Descriptions:toString() on  aLimiter will replace StringParser.descriptionOfValidValues(Locale) in the usage. 
 A simpler alternative to provide a description is to use limitTo(Predicate, String).

 Supplied default values:The validity of any default value isn't checked until
 it's actually needed when ParsedArguments.get(Argument) is called. This is so
 because Supplier.get() (or StringParser.defaultValue()) could take an arbitrary long time.

 Many limiters:Any previously set limiter will be and'ed together with  aLimiter.
 
 Interopability with completers Values suggested with any completer(Function) will not be limited automatically. 
 So before generating the suggestions, you should make sure that they are confirming to your limiter.
        Parameters:
        aLimiter - a limiter
        Returns:
        this builder

      • limitTo

        public SELF limitTo(Predicate<? super T> aLimiter,
                    Describable aDescription)
        Like limitTo(Predicate, String) but allows for lazy construction of the description

      • limitTo

        public SELF limitTo(Predicate<? super T> aLimiter,
                    String aDescription)
        Like limitTo(Predicate) but with aDescription to describe the valid values this limiter accepts
        Returns:
        this builder

      • metaDescription

        public final SELF metaDescription(String aMetaDescription)
         By default StringParsers provides a meta description (by implementing StringParser.metaDescription()
 that describes the type of data they expect. For instance, if you're writing a music player,
 a user of your application would (most probably) rather see:

 --track-nr <track nr>    The track number to play (using   metaDescription("<track nr>") )

 instead of

 --track-nr <integer>     The track number to play (the default provided by StringParser.metaDescription())

 So when using general data type parsers such as StringParsers.integerParser() you're better of if
 you provide a meta description that explains what the  integer represents in the context of this argument.

 Note: empty meta descriptions aren't allowed
 Note: the surrounding < and > aren't enforced or added automatically but it's preferred
 to have them because it makes a clear distinction between argument names and their parameters.

 @param aMetaDescription "<track nr>" in the above example
 @return this builder
 @throws IllegalArgumentException if aMetaDescription is empty

      • names

        public SELF names(Iterable<String> argumentNames)
        Works just like names(String...) but it takes an Iterable instead.
        Parameters:
        argumentNames - the list to use as argument names
        Returns:
        this builder

      • names

        public SELF names(String... argumentNames)
        Specifies the argument names that triggers the argument being built. As commands sometimes gets long and hard to understand it's recommended to also support long named arguments, making the commands even longer but more readable instead
        Parameters:
        argumentNames -
        • "-o" for a short named option/argument
        • "--option-name" for a long named option/argument
        • "-o", "--option-name" to give the user both choices
        • zero elements: makes this an indexed argument, meaning that the argument must be given at the same position on the command line as it is given to CommandLineParser.withArguments(Argument...) (not counting named arguments).
        Returns:
        this builder

      • parse

        @Nullable
public final T parse(String... actualArguments)
                        throws ArgumentException
         Parses command line arguments and returns the value of the argument built
 by build(), providing a simple one liner shortcut when faced with only one argument.
 
         
 String[] args = {"--listen-port", "8090"};

 int port = integerArgument("-p", "--listen-port").defaultValue(8080).description("The port clients should connect to.").parse(args);
 assertThat(port).isEqualTo(8090);
        This is a shorthand method that should be used if only one Argument is expected as it will throw if unexpected arguments are encountered. If several arguments are expected use CommandLineParser.withArguments(Argument...) instead.
        Parameters:
        actualArguments - the arguments from the command line
        Returns:
        the parsed value from the actualArguments
        Throws:
        ArgumentException - if actualArguments isn't compatible with this argument

      • parser

        @Nonnull
protected abstract StringParser<T> parser()
         Returns a customized parser that the Argument will use to parse values.

 This is a suitable place to verify the configuration of your parser.

 If your StringParser doesn't support any configuration you can use
 Arguments.withParser(StringParser) directly instead of subclassing
 ArgumentBuilder

 @return the StringParser that performs the actual parsing of an argument value
 @throws IllegalStateException if the parser have been configured wrongly

      • repeated

        @CheckReturnValue
public ArgumentBuilder.RepeatedArgumentBuilder<T> repeated()
        Makes it possible to enter several values for the same argument. Such as this: 
         
 String[] arguments = {"--number", "1", "--number", "2"};
 List<Integer> numbers = integerArgument("--number").repeated().parse(arguments);
 assertThat(numbers).isEqualTo(asList(1, 2));
        If you want to combine repeated() with a specific arity(int) then call arity(int) before calling repeated(): 
         
 String[] arguments = {"--numbers", "1", "2", "--numbers", "3", "4"};
 List<List<Integer>> numberLists = integerArgument("--numbers").arity(2).repeated().parse(arguments);
 assertThat(numberLists).isEqualTo(asList(asList(1, 2), asList(3, 4)));
        For repeated values in a property map such as this: 
         
 String[] arguments = {"-Nnumber=1", "-Nnumber=2"};
 Map<String, List<Integer>> numberMap = integerArgument("-N").repeated().asPropertyMap().parse(arguments);
 assertThat(numberMap.get("number")).isEqualTo(asList(1, 2));
        repeated() should be called before asPropertyMap(). For arguments without a name (indexed arguments) use variableArity() instead.
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder

      • required

        public SELF required()
         Makes CommandLineParser.parse(String...) throw
 ArgumentException if this argument isn't given.
 If possible, it's preferred to use a default value instead.

 The Argument.toString() will be used to print each missing argument.

 Note: If you choose to use multiple required() indexed arguments all of them
 must have unique metaDescription(String)s. This ensures that error messages
 can point out erroneous arguments better

 @return this builder
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if defaultValue(Object) (or defaultValueSupplier(Supplier)) has been called, because these are mutually exclusive with required()

      • separator

        public SELF separator(String aSeparator)
        For instance, "=" in --author=jjonsson
        Parameters:
        aSeparator - the character that separates the argument name and argument value, defaults to a space
        Returns:
        this builder

      • splitWith

        @CheckReturnValue
public ArgumentBuilder.SplitterArgumentBuilder<T> splitWith(String valueSeparator)
         When given a "," this allows for
 arguments such as:
 -numbers 1,2,3
 where the resulting  List&lt;Integer&gt; would contain 1, 2 and 3.

 Note: Doesn't allow empty lists. Leading and trailing whitespace will be trimmed for each element.
        Parameters:
        valueSeparator - the string to split the input with
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object

      • transform

        @CheckReturnValue
public <F> ArgumentBuilder.TransformingArgumentBuilder<F> transform(Function<T,F> transformer)
        Makes it possible to chain together different transformation / map / conversion operations 
         
 int size = Arguments.stringArgument("--foo").transform(String::length).parse("--foo", "abcd");
 assertThat(size).isEqualTo(4);
        Parameters:
        transformer - the function that takes a value of the previous type (like String in the example), and converts it into another type of value
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder

      • usage

        public final Usage usage()
        Returns a usage string for the argument that this builder builds. Should only be used if one argument is supported, otherwise the CommandLineParser.usage() method should be used instead.

      • variableArity

        @CheckReturnValue
public ArgumentBuilder.ArityArgumentBuilder<T> variableArity()
        Useful for handling a variable amount of parameters in the end of a command. Uses this argument to parse values but assumes that all the following parameters are of the same type, integer in the following example: 
         
 String[] threeArgs = {"--numbers", "1", "2", "3"};
 List<Integer> numbers = integerArgument("--numbers").variableArity().parse(threeArgs);
 assertThat(numbers).isEqualTo(asList(1, 2, 3));

 String[] twoArgs = {"--numbers", "1", "2"};
 List<Integer> numbers = integerArgument("--numbers").variableArity().parse(twoArgs);
 assertThat(numbers).isEqualTo(asList(1, 2));
        Note: if default value has been set before variableArity() is called the default value will be a list with that one element in it, otherwise it will be empty.
        Returns:
        a new (more specific) builder
